title: HACCP/APPCC System
legalBasis: EU Regulation (EC) No 852/2004 on the hygiene of foodstuffs; Codex Alimentarius General Principles of Food Hygiene (CXC 1-1969); Spanish Royal Decree 640/2006
summary:
The Hazard Analysis and Critical Control Points (HACCP) system — known as APPCC (Análisis de Peligros y Puntos de Control Crítico) in Spain — is a systematic, science-based approach to food safety management mandated by EU Regulation 852/2004. Every food business operator in the European Union must implement, maintain, and regularly review HACCP-based procedures. The system focuses on identifying, evaluating, and controlling hazards that are significant to food safety rather than relying solely on end-product testing.

For hospitality establishments such as restaurants, bars, and catering operations, a properly implemented HACCP system ensures that biological, chemical, and physical hazards are identified at every stage of food handling — from receipt of raw materials through storage, preparation, cooking, holding, and service. The seven principles of HACCP provide a structured framework that, when combined with prerequisite programmes (cleaning, pest control, staff training), creates a comprehensive food safety management system.

Compliance is not optional: failure to implement HACCP-based procedures can result in enforcement action by competent authorities, including improvement notices, prohibition orders, and financial penalties. More importantly, a robust HACCP system protects your customers from foodborne illness and your business from reputational damage.
keyPoints: HACCP is legally required for all food business operators under EU Regulation 852/2004, Article 5
The system is based on seven internationally recognised principles established by the Codex Alimentarius Commission
HACCP must be supported by prerequisite programmes such as cleaning, pest control, and staff training
Documentation and record-keeping are essential for demonstrating compliance during official inspections
The HACCP plan must be reviewed whenever processes, products, or equipment change
Each Critical Control Point (CCP) must have defined critical limits, monitoring procedures, and corrective actions
A multidisciplinary HACCP team should be established, with at least one member having formal HACCP training
Spanish businesses must also comply with Royal Decree 640/2006 regarding specific hygiene rules

sections.heading: 1. Introduction to HACCP
sections.content:
The HACCP system was originally developed in the 1960s by the Pillsbury Company in collaboration with NASA and the US Army Natick Research Laboratories to ensure the safety of food for space missions. It has since been adopted worldwide as the gold standard for food safety management. In the European Union, HACCP-based procedures became a legal requirement with the adoption of Regulation (EC) No 852/2004, which applies to all food business operators at all stages of production, processing, and distribution.

The fundamental philosophy of HACCP is prevention rather than reaction. Instead of relying on end-product inspection and testing — which can only ever sample a small fraction of output — HACCP identifies the points in a process where hazards can be prevented, eliminated, or reduced to acceptable levels. This proactive approach is both more effective and more cost-efficient than traditional quality control methods.

For hospitality businesses, HACCP provides a structured way to manage the inherent risks of handling, preparing, and serving food to the public. Whether you operate a small tapas bar or a large hotel kitchen, the principles remain the same, though the complexity of your HACCP plan will reflect the scale and nature of your operations.

subsections.heading: 1.1 Legal Framework
subsections.content:
EU Regulation (EC) No 852/2004 establishes general hygiene requirements for all food business operators and, in Article 5, specifically requires the implementation of procedures based on HACCP principles. The regulation emphasises flexibility, recognising that HACCP procedures should be proportionate to the size and nature of the business. This flexibility provision is particularly relevant for small hospitality establishments.

In Spain, the regulation is complemented by Royal Decree 640/2006, which establishes specific conditions for the application of EU hygiene requirements. Regional autonomous communities may also have additional requirements. Food business operators must ensure their HACCP plans comply with all applicable legislation at EU, national, and regional levels.

subsections.heading: 1.2 Scope and Application
subsections.content:
HACCP applies to all operations within a food business where food is handled, processed, stored, or served. In a hospitality setting, this encompasses receiving deliveries, dry and refrigerated storage, thawing, preparation, cooking, hot and cold holding, cooling, reheating, plating, service, and the management of leftovers. Each of these stages must be evaluated for potential hazards.

The system does not replace basic hygiene practices (prerequisite programmes) but builds upon them. Prerequisite programmes — including cleaning and disinfection, pest control, water supply management, waste management, staff hygiene, and maintenance — must be in place before HACCP analysis begins. Without solid prerequisite programmes, the HACCP system cannot function effectively.

subsections.heading: 1.3 Benefits for Hospitality Businesses
subsections.content:
Beyond legal compliance, a well-implemented HACCP system delivers tangible business benefits. It reduces the risk of foodborne illness outbreaks that can devastate a hospitality business through lost customers, negative reviews, and potential litigation. It provides a framework for consistent food safety standards regardless of staff turnover. It creates documentation that demonstrates due diligence in the event of a complaint or investigation.

HACCP also drives operational efficiency by standardising procedures, reducing waste from spoiled or contaminated food, and providing a basis for continuous improvement. Many hospitality businesses find that the discipline of HACCP implementation leads to better overall kitchen management and more consistent food quality.

sections.heading: 2. The Seven Principles of HACCP
sections.content:
The HACCP system is built on seven principles that provide a logical sequence for identifying and controlling food safety hazards. These principles, as defined by the Codex Alimentarius Commission and adopted by EU legislation, form the core methodology that every food business operator must follow. Understanding and correctly applying these principles is essential for building an effective HACCP plan.

The seven principles are interconnected and should be applied systematically. Skipping or inadequately addressing any principle weakens the entire system. In a hospitality context, the application of these principles must be practical and workable within the realities of a busy kitchen environment.

subsections.heading: 2.1 Principles 1-3: Hazard Analysis, CCP Identification, and Critical Limits
subsections.content:
Principle 1 requires conducting a thorough hazard analysis: identifying all potential biological (bacteria, viruses, parasites), chemical (cleaning agents, allergens, pesticides), and physical (glass, metal, bone fragments) hazards at each step of the food handling process. For each identified hazard, you must assess the likelihood of occurrence and the severity of consequences, then determine what preventive measures can be applied.

Principle 2 involves determining the Critical Control Points (CCPs) — the steps in the process where control can be applied and is essential to prevent or eliminate a food safety hazard or reduce it to an acceptable level. A decision tree can help identify CCPs systematically. Principle 3 requires establishing critical limits for each CCP — measurable values that separate acceptability from unacceptability, such as a minimum cooking temperature of 75°C for poultry.

subsections.heading: 2.2 Principles 4-5: Monitoring and Corrective Actions
subsections.content:
Principle 4 establishes monitoring procedures for each CCP — planned measurements or observations to assess whether a CCP is under control. Monitoring must be frequent enough to detect loss of control in a timely manner. In a restaurant kitchen, this includes activities such as checking refrigerator temperatures at regular intervals, measuring core cooking temperatures with calibrated probes, and verifying oil temperatures in fryers.

Principle 5 defines the corrective actions to be taken when monitoring indicates that a CCP is not under control (i.e., a critical limit has been breached). Corrective actions must address both the immediate situation (what happens to the affected food) and the cause of the deviation (why did the critical limit breach occur and how can it be prevented in future). All corrective actions must be documented.

subsections.heading: 2.3 Principles 6-7: Verification and Documentation
subsections.content:
Principle 6 requires verification procedures to confirm that the HACCP system is working effectively. Verification is distinct from monitoring: while monitoring checks whether CCPs are under control during operations, verification checks whether the HACCP system as a whole is valid and properly implemented. Verification activities include reviewing monitoring records, calibrating measuring instruments, conducting microbiological testing, and performing internal audits.

Principle 7 mandates documentation and record-keeping. All HACCP procedures and records must be documented and maintained. Documentation includes the HACCP plan itself (hazard analysis, CCP determination, critical limits, monitoring procedures, corrective actions, verification procedures) and operational records (monitoring results, corrective action records, verification records). The level of documentation should be proportionate to the nature and size of the business.

sections.heading: 3. Preliminary Steps Before HACCP Implementation
sections.content:
Before applying the seven principles, the Codex Alimentarius recommends five preliminary steps that lay the foundation for a successful HACCP plan. These preparatory activities ensure that the HACCP team has the knowledge, information, and resources needed to conduct a thorough and accurate hazard analysis. Skipping these steps is a common cause of ineffective HACCP plans.

These preliminary steps are particularly important in hospitality, where menus change frequently, staff turnover can be high, and multiple products are prepared simultaneously in shared facilities. Taking the time to complete these steps properly will make the subsequent HACCP analysis more focused and practical.

subsections.heading: 3.1 Assembling the HACCP Team
subsections.content:
The HACCP team should include individuals with expertise in the food operations of the business. In a restaurant, this typically includes the head chef or kitchen manager, a food safety specialist (which may be an external consultant), and representatives from front-of-house service. At least one team member should have received formal HACCP training. The team should collectively have knowledge of food science, food safety hazards, the specific operations of the establishment, and the applicable legal requirements.

The team leader should have the authority to implement changes and allocate resources. In smaller establishments, the team may consist of just two or three people, but it is important that the team includes someone with hands-on experience of the daily kitchen operations and someone with food safety expertise.

subsections.heading: 3.2 Product Description and Intended Use
subsections.content:
For each product or category of products, the team must prepare a full description including ingredients, processing methods, packaging, storage conditions, shelf life, and distribution methods. In a restaurant context, this may be organised by product category (e.g., raw meat dishes, cooked meat dishes, salads, desserts) rather than by individual menu items.

The intended use must also be defined, including the target consumer group. This is particularly important where vulnerable populations may be served — for example, children's menus, elderly care catering, or dishes for customers with allergies or intolerances. The identification of vulnerable consumers may influence the stringency of critical limits and control measures.

subsections.heading: 3.3 Flow Diagrams and On-Site Verification
subsections.content:
The HACCP team must construct flow diagrams covering all steps in the operation for each product or process category. In a restaurant, a typical flow diagram covers: receiving → storage → preparation → cooking → hot holding/cold holding → service → management of leftovers. The flow diagram should also show the physical layout of the kitchen and any potential cross-contamination routes between raw and cooked foods.

Once constructed, flow diagrams must be verified on-site during actual operations. This step ensures that the diagrams accurately reflect what happens in practice, not just what is supposed to happen. On-site verification often reveals deviations from planned procedures, informal practices, and potential hazards that were not apparent from a desk-based analysis.

sections.heading: 4. Implementing HACCP in a Hospitality Setting
sections.content:
Implementing HACCP in a restaurant, bar, or catering operation presents unique challenges compared to a food manufacturing environment. Hospitality businesses typically handle a wide variety of products, prepare dishes to order with short lead times, operate with variable staffing, and must balance food safety with the demands of service. The HACCP plan must be practical and workable within these constraints.

Successful implementation requires a phased approach: establishing prerequisite programmes first, then conducting the hazard analysis and developing the HACCP plan, followed by staff training, and finally ongoing monitoring, verification, and review. Trying to implement everything at once often leads to an overly complex system that staff cannot follow consistently.

subsections.heading: 4.1 Common CCPs in Hospitality
subsections.content:
While each establishment must conduct its own hazard analysis, certain CCPs are common across hospitality businesses. Cooking is almost always a CCP, with critical limits based on time-temperature combinations sufficient to destroy pathogenic microorganisms (e.g., 75°C core temperature for at least 15 seconds). Chilling and cold storage are typically CCPs, with critical limits of 5°C or below for refrigerated storage and rapid cooling from 63°C to 10°C within specified time frames.

Hot holding (maintaining cooked food at 63°C or above), receiving (checking delivery temperatures), and reheating (achieving 75°C core temperature) are also commonly identified as CCPs. Cross-contamination prevention during preparation, particularly the separation of raw and ready-to-eat foods, may be managed as a CCP or through prerequisite programmes depending on the specific risk assessment.

subsections.heading: 4.2 Monitoring in a Busy Kitchen
subsections.content:
Monitoring procedures must be designed for the reality of a busy service period. Temperature checks should be quick and unobtrusive — digital probe thermometers that give rapid readings are essential. Recording systems should be simple: pre-printed checklists with tick boxes and spaces for temperature readings are more practical than narrative records. Increasingly, automated monitoring systems with wireless temperature sensors and digital logging are available and can significantly reduce the monitoring burden.

Responsibility for monitoring should be clearly assigned. Each staff member must know exactly which checks they are responsible for, when to perform them, and how to record the results. Monitoring during peak service periods requires particular attention — this is when shortcuts are most tempting and the consequences of failure are greatest.

subsections.heading: 4.3 Record-Keeping and Documentation
subsections.content:
EU Regulation 852/2004 requires that documentation and records be commensurate with the nature and size of the food business. For a small restaurant, a simple system of daily temperature logs, cleaning schedules, delivery records, and corrective action forms may be sufficient. Larger operations may benefit from digital record-keeping systems that automate data capture and provide alerts when parameters deviate from normal ranges.

Records must be retained for a reasonable period — typically at least two years, though specific requirements may vary by autonomous community. Records should be readily available for inspection by competent authorities. A well-organised filing system, whether paper-based or digital, is essential. Key records include: temperature monitoring logs, corrective action records, cleaning and disinfection records, pest control reports, staff training records, supplier approval documentation, and HACCP plan review minutes.

sections.heading: 5. Verification and Continuous Improvement
sections.content:
A HACCP system is not a static document — it is a living management system that must be regularly verified, reviewed, and updated. Verification activities confirm that the system is working as intended and that food safety hazards are being effectively controlled. Without regular verification, a HACCP system can become outdated and ineffective, providing a false sense of security.

Continuous improvement is embedded in the HACCP methodology. Every corrective action, every verification finding, and every review should be seen as an opportunity to strengthen the system. The goal is not perfection from day one, but a systematic, evidence-based approach to progressively reducing food safety risks.

subsections.heading: 5.1 Internal Audits and Reviews
subsections.content:
Internal audits should be conducted at least annually, and more frequently for high-risk operations. An internal audit systematically evaluates whether HACCP procedures are being followed in practice, whether monitoring records are complete and accurate, whether corrective actions have been effective, and whether the HACCP plan remains appropriate for current operations. Audit findings should be documented and any non-conformities addressed promptly.

The HACCP plan must be reviewed whenever there is a change that could affect the hazard analysis. Triggers for review include: menu changes, new equipment, changes to kitchen layout, new suppliers, changes in legislation, food safety incidents, customer complaints related to food safety, and results of microbiological testing or official inspections.

subsections.heading: 5.2 Validation and Calibration
subsections.content:
Validation confirms that the HACCP plan, if properly implemented, will effectively control the identified hazards. This is distinct from verification, which confirms that the plan is being properly implemented. Validation activities may include scientific literature review, expert consultation, microbiological challenge testing, and analysis of historical monitoring data.

Calibration of measuring instruments — particularly thermometers — is a critical verification activity. Probe thermometers should be calibrated regularly against a known standard (e.g., ice-water bath at 0°C, boiling water at 100°C). Calibration records must be maintained. Using uncalibrated instruments can render all temperature monitoring data unreliable, undermining the entire HACCP system.

sections.heading: 6. Official Controls and Enforcement
sections.content:
Competent authorities conduct official controls to verify that food business operators are complying with food law, including the requirement to implement HACCP-based procedures. In Spain, official food safety inspections are carried out by health inspectors from the autonomous communities, who assess both the HACCP documentation and its practical implementation. Understanding what inspectors look for can help you prepare for and respond to official controls.

Inspectors evaluate not just whether a HACCP plan exists on paper, but whether it is effectively implemented in practice. They will observe operations, interview staff, review records, and may take samples for laboratory analysis. A well-maintained HACCP system with complete, accurate records is the best preparation for any inspection.

subsections.heading: 6.1 Inspection Priorities
subsections.content:
Inspectors typically focus on high-risk areas: temperature control (cooking, cooling, cold and hot holding), cross-contamination prevention (separation of raw and ready-to-eat foods), personal hygiene practices, cleaning and disinfection effectiveness, and allergen management. They will review temperature monitoring records for completeness, accuracy, and evidence of corrective actions when deviations occurred.

Inspectors also assess the HACCP team's competence — whether staff can explain the CCPs relevant to their work, what the critical limits are, and what they should do if a limit is breached. A HACCP plan that exists only as a document in the manager's office, unknown to the kitchen staff who must implement it daily, will not satisfy an inspector.

subsections.heading: 6.2 Responding to Non-Conformities
subsections.content:
If an inspection identifies non-conformities, the food business operator must take prompt corrective action. Minor non-conformities may result in recommendations or improvement notices with deadlines for compliance. Serious non-conformities — such as critical temperature failures, evidence of pest infestation, or absence of any HACCP procedures — may result in enforcement action including prohibition notices, product withdrawal or recall, and financial penalties.

The best approach is to treat inspection findings as opportunities for improvement. Document all corrective actions taken, including root cause analysis and measures to prevent recurrence. Follow up with the competent authority to confirm that corrective actions are satisfactory. Maintaining a constructive relationship with your local health inspection team is valuable for ongoing compliance.

checklists.title: Daily HACCP Monitoring Checklist
items: Check and record all refrigerator temperatures (must be ≤5°C)
Check and record all freezer temperatures (must be ≤-18°C)
Verify hot holding equipment temperatures (must be ≥63°C)
Check probe thermometer calibration (ice-water test: 0°C ±1°C)
Record core cooking temperatures for high-risk dishes (must reach ≥75°C)
Verify that raw and ready-to-eat foods are stored separately
Check that all food items are properly labelled with date of preparation
Review any deliveries received — check temperatures, condition, and use-by dates
Confirm cleaning schedule tasks have been completed and signed off
Document any corrective actions taken for deviations from critical limits

checklists.title: Weekly HACCP Review Checklist
items: Review all daily monitoring records for completeness and accuracy
Verify that all corrective actions from the past week have been resolved
Check calibration status of all thermometers and measuring equipment
Review cleaning and disinfection records for compliance with the plan
Check pest control monitoring stations and report any findings
Verify supplier documentation is up to date (certificates, delivery notes)
Assess staff compliance with personal hygiene requirements
Update HACCP records filing system — ensure all documents are properly stored

checklists.title: Annual HACCP System Review Checklist
items: Conduct a full internal audit of the HACCP system
Review and update the hazard analysis for any menu or process changes
Verify that all CCPs and critical limits remain valid and appropriate
Review and update flow diagrams to reflect current operations
Assess training records — ensure all staff have current food safety training
Review supplier approval status and documentation
Evaluate monitoring procedures for effectiveness and practicality
Review corrective action records for recurring issues
Update HACCP documentation to reflect any changes
Document the review findings and any actions required

bestPractices: Keep the HACCP plan practical and proportionate — avoid unnecessary complexity that makes the system difficult for kitchen staff to follow consistently
Train all food handlers on the specific CCPs relevant to their work, not just general food safety principles
Use digital temperature monitoring and logging systems where possible to reduce manual recording burden and improve accuracy
Conduct regular unannounced internal checks to verify that HACCP procedures are being followed during actual service periods
Maintain a clear corrective action procedure that empowers all staff to take immediate action when a critical limit is breached
Review the HACCP plan immediately whenever there is a significant change to the menu, equipment, suppliers, or kitchen layout
Keep monitoring forms simple and accessible — they should be at the point of use, not locked in an office
Establish a food safety culture where every team member understands that food safety is everyone's responsibility, not just the manager's

glossary.HACCP: Hazard Analysis and Critical Control Points — a systematic preventive approach to food safety that identifies physical, biological, and chemical hazards in production processes
glossary.APPCC: Análisis de Peligros y Puntos de Control Crítico — the Spanish term for HACCP
glossary.CCP: Critical Control Point — a step at which control can be applied and is essential to prevent or eliminate a food safety hazard or reduce it to an acceptable level
glossary.Critical Limit: A measurable value that separates acceptability from unacceptability at a Critical Control Point (e.g., minimum cooking temperature of 75°C)
glossary.Hazard: A biological, chemical, or physical agent in, or condition of, food with the potential to cause an adverse health effect
glossary.Monitoring: The planned sequence of observations or measurements to assess whether a CCP is under control and to produce an accurate record for future use in verification
glossary.Corrective Action: Any action to be taken when the results of monitoring at a CCP indicate a loss of control (deviation from a critical limit)
glossary.Verification: The application of methods, procedures, tests, and other evaluations, in addition to monitoring, to determine compliance with the HACCP plan
glossary.Prerequisite Programme: Basic conditions and activities necessary to maintain a hygienic environment for the production, handling, and provision of safe food (e.g., cleaning, pest control, staff hygiene)
glossary.Validation: Obtaining evidence that the elements of the HACCP plan are effective — confirming that the control measures, if properly implemented, are capable of controlling the identified hazards
